awd_titl_txt: Noyce Scholars Program Phase II: Expanding the Model
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, Hofstra University will partner with Nassau Community College (NCC) and four high-need school districts on Long Island, for this Scholarships & Stipends Phase II project, Noyce Scholars Program Phase II: Expanding the Model. The project will support 22 juniors/seniors/post-baccalaureate students who are majoring in mathematics or a science discipline (or who have completed such a major) and who are preparing to teach secondary mathematics or science in a high-need district. Each Scholar will receive 1 or 2 years of scholarship support. The new teachers will use vetted methods of mathematics and science instruction, connecting concepts across disciplines and engaging learners in collaborative problem solving related to real world contexts.

Building on the Phase I project, this project will offer an enhanced preparation and development program with seven components specifically developed and refined based on Phase I project evaluation. Project activities include: (a) an enhanced new recruitment program; (b) STEM internships for freshman and sophomore students; (c) immersive early teaching experiences: (d) coaching of cooperating teachers in high-need school districts; (e) regular colloquia, conferences, and institutes; (f) leadership roles for Phase I alumni; and (g) an induction initiative for new teachers. The project will use quantitative and qualitative data to address research questions such as: (1) What are the longitudinal outcomes of Phase 1 Scholars, including their commitment to STEM teaching; service commitment years; perceptions of their preparedness to teach in high-need schools, retainment/support activities; and quality of teaching STEM in high-need schools? (2) To what extent does the integration of cooperating teachers into teacher preparation activities contribute to the preparedness and retention of Scholars?

por.por_cntn:
This brief report focuses on three areas: (1) the number of scholars supported by the Noyce Program, (2) what was gained through mentorship, and  (3) the research articles (published and under review) that contributes to the knowledge base in teacher education 

 

Supported 26 Noyce Scholars (12 are undergraduates and 14 are graduate student. In total, 77% of the students majored in mathematics and 23% majored in science. Six identified themselves as non-Caucasian.) 

 

Mentoring - The mentoring program was largely for those who were out in the field doing student teaching. The networking opportunities that the Summer Institute help facilitate proves to be highly instrumental in forging relationship between scholars that in turn help mentoring. Since schools in Long Island and New York City provide one-on-one mentors, the Hofstra Noyce program is nimble in not duplicating that service. So, we are letting the mentorship stem from the relationship. This approach has been quite effective. For example, while the the total number of scholars supported by both Noyce I and II is 49, seven of them (that is, 14% of  Hofstra Scholars) are teaching in one of the partner high-need school district: Uniondale. Most of these highly effective math and science teachers are tenured and have completed the Noyce commitment, but they are still teaching in the district and playing key role in teaching and learning. This remarkable success is partly attributed to the Hofstra Noyce Mentoring program. 

 

Publications: Listed below are the research articles published and under review. They contribute to broadening the knowledge base in the area of teacher education.  

Published:

  • Developing preservice teacher self-efficacy through peer tutoring. The Teacher Educator. (with DeFeo, D. J, & Tran, T. C. (2022)).
  • Correlations between professional noticing of students? mathematical thinking and specialized content knowledge, (2019). Proceedings of the 41st Annual Meeting of the North American
  • Chapter of the International Group for Psychology of Mathematics Education (pp. 725-730).St. Louis, MO: University of Missouri (with R. LaRochelle)
  • A Window into New Teachers Minds, 73 (2016), Educational Leadership (with J. Brooks) Under Review: ? Teaching dispositions in tutoring: Evidence in a college math lab. (with DeFeo, D.J.

Under Review:

  • Teaching dispositions in tutoring: Evidence in a college math lab. (with DeFeo, D.J.)

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2023
Modified by: Behailu Mammo
